infodynamics.measures.continuous

Class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon

  • java.lang.Object
    • infodynamics.measures.continuous.ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov

    public abstract class ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
extends java.lang.Object
implements ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
    Implements ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate to provide a base class with common functionality for child class implementations of ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate via various estimators.

    These various estimators include: e.g. box-kernel estimation, KSG estimators, etc (see the child classes linked above).

    Usage is as outlined in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.

    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)

      • var1Observations

        protected double[][] var1Observations
        The set of observations for var1, retained in case the user wants to retrieve the local entropy values of these. They're held in the order in which they were supplied in the addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) functions.

        protected double[][] var2Observations
        The set of observations for var2, retained in case the user wants to retrieve the local entropy values of these. They're held in the order in which they were supplied in the addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) functions.

        The set of observations for the conditional, retained in case the user wants to retrieve the local entropy values of these. They're held in the order in which they were supplied in the addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) functions.

              int condDimensions)

      • setProperty

        public void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
        Set properties for the calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, include:

        • PROP_NORMALISE - whether to normalise the individual variables to mean 0, standard deviation 1 (true by default, except for child class ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian)

        Unknown property values are ignored.

        Specified by:
        setProperty in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        public void setObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF. Cannot be called in conjunction with ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.startAddObservations() / ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int) / ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.finaliseAddObservations().

        The supplied series may be (multivariate) time-series or simply a set of separate observations without a time interpretation.

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.startAddObservations(); call ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Note that the arrays must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        public void addObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond,
                   int startTime,
                   int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

        Adds a new sub-series of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.startAddObservations(); call ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Note that the arrays must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Specified by:
        addObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first time index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of time steps to use (including startTime)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF, where all the various observations are valid. Cannot be called in conjunction with ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.startAddObservations() / ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int) / ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.finaliseAddObservations().

        Specified by:
        setObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        var1Valid - series (with indices the same as var1) indicating whether var1 at that point is valid.
        var2Valid - series (with indices the same as var2) indicating whether var2 at that point is valid.
        condValid - series (with indices the same as cond) indicating whether cond at that point is valid.

        java.lang.Exception

        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        var1Valid - series (with indices the same as var1) indicating whether each variable of var1 at that point is valid.
        var2Valid - series (with indices the same as var2) indicating whether each variable of var2 at that point is valid.
        condValid - series (with indices the same as cond) indicating whether each variable of cond at that point is valid.

      • finaliseAddObservations

        public void finaliseAddObservations()
                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed. This default implementation simply puts all of the observations into the var1Observations, var2Observations and condObservations arrays. Usually child implementations will override this, call this implementation to perform the common processing, then perform their own processing.
        Specified by:
        finaliseAddObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Allow child classes to throw an exception if there is an issue detected specific to that calculator.

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int variableToReorder,
                                                   int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the conditional MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the variable identified by variableToReorder had no relation to the other variable, given the conditional.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for conditional MI. Basically, we shuffle the observations of variableToReorder against the other variable and the conditional. This keeps the marginal and joint PDFs of the unshuffled variable and conditional the same but destroys any correlation between the named variable and the others.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.computeSignificance(int, int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate AIS calculations.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        public EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int variableToReorder,
                                                   int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

        As described in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.computeSignificance(int, int[][])

        Here we provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        Specified by:
        computeSignificance in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the values of the variable specified by variableToReorder to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int variableToReorder,
                                       int[] newOrdering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception

        As described in ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int, int[])

        We provide a simple implementation which would be suitable for any child class, though the child class may prefer to make its own implementation to make class-specific optimisations. Child classes must implement Cloneable for this method to be callable for them, and indeed implement the clone() method in a way that protects their structure from alteration by surrogate data being supplied to it.

        Specified by:
        computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        newOrdering - permutation of the indices for the given variable; must be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate.getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        conditional MI under this reordering
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • getLastAverage

        public double getLastAverage()

        Specified by:
        getLastAverage in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
        Returns:

                       throws java.lang.Exception

      • computeStartAndEndTimePairs

        public java.util.Vector<int[]> computeStartAndEndTimePairs(boolean[] var1Valid,
                                                  boolean[] var2Valid,
                                                  boolean[] condValid)
        Compute a vector of start and end pairs of time points, between which we have valid series of all variables. Made public so it can be used if one wants to compute the number of observations prior to setting the observations.
        Parameters:
        var1Valid - a series (indexed by observation number or time) indicating whether the entry in observations at that index is valid for variable 1;
        var2Valid - as described for var1Valid
        condValid - as described for var1Valid
        Returns:
        a vector for start and end time pairs of valid series of observations.

        Specified by:
        getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
